answers.answer: Yes, you should be worried.  The calcification means plaque is building in your arteries throughout your body.  They can result in a total blockage of one or more arteries (like your mom had).  You need to eat healthy, lose some weight not only for this, but for your diabetes and overall health.  I've watched my husband go thru many problems and surgeries due to calcifications, along with diabetes.  I don't mean to ne harsh, but since heart disease is in your family, it increases your risks for it, and all your health problems, and weight increase it also.  Please get yourself healthy.

question: I recently had a chest CT that showed aortic calcification but and Echo 2 weeks prior did not pick it up.  Is this common?, and when should I worry about this calcium build up.  A little background:I had the CT because of ? about asthma diagnosis.  I am a large woman, although I hate the word obese is correct wording.  My mom had a triple by-pass about 7 years ago. I am diabetic and on simvastatin my cholesterol is down to 165.  I'm a little freaked out right now, any advise would be appreciated.
title: Aortic calcification
